data.title: Madame Butterfly (2009)
data.meta_description: Free interpretation of the myth. Tsai Ming-liang propels a woman neglected by her lover in the mob of the bus station of Kuala Lumpur.
data.text:
I made a video essay: What Is Slow Cinema?

I was very excited to receive my blu-ray copy of the new 4K restoration of Tsai's Goodbye, Dragon Inn (which I will review soon), but I was just as excited to see that it contained one of the few Tsai shorts that I couldn't find online.

This loose adaptation of a Puccini opera effectively conveys the protagonist's sense of isolation and displacement. A 20-minute long, handheld camera take follows the protagonist as she meanders inside the Kuala Lumpur bus station where her boyfriend left her stranded and penniless. She desperately searches for a direction, her panic and disorientation slowly building up.

A second, briefer shot lingers on her face as she…

Asian strip malls are a bombardment, and a lurid, fecund one at that. The Equatorial humidity ensures that buildings never stay pristine for long. New constructions crumble and fade, becoming dull and moisture-logged - dirt sticks to walls, becomes one with floor tiles regardless of the frequency with which they're mopped. All that stifling, damp air clings to odours: the sticky sweet powdery perfumes, the overripe fruit, the tart, sooty trails of exhaust fumes and pollution that seep in from outside, and the bitter lingering scent of the thronging masses as they sweat their way through each day. Take air-conditioning out of the equation and it all hangs and lingers with a livid dankness that much heavier, more pregnant.

Perhaps…

It takes less than thirty seconds to realise how divorced Madame Butterfly is from Tsai Ming-liang's usual aesthetic. Stillness is the move with Tsai, yet here he has a camera constantly adrift, following a woman who too is without direction after having been neglected by her lover. The stop/start rhythm of flows in sync with the woman's situation, as she seeks avenues of support only to be cast down once more.

Due to the nature of the production (shot in an actively operating terminal), a lot of the citizens wandering about look directly into the camera, observing a filmmaking process that normally remains purely contemplative in Tsai's more recent works (particularly Walker and Journey to the West).
